Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Unmanned Aerial System Datasets from Hurricanes Harvey and Irma

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This 12-month RAPID project will organize unmanned aerial system (UAS) data from 119 flights at Hurricane Harvey and 247 at Hurricane Irma, in order to make the data available to researchers. The project will (1) screen for personal privacy identification and applicable state laws, and make available to researchers, (2) host a virtual workshop to introduce the dataset and access procedures for researchers, and (3) host a follow up workshop at the 2018 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security and Rescue Robotics to discuss the results by researchers using the datasets and how to acquire datasets in the future.

The datasets were collected by the Texas A&M Engineering Experiment Station and Florida State University who co-deployed to Fort Bend County, Texas, and Putnam and Collier Counties, Florida. They are unique because they (1) reflect the largest number of flights for public officials; (2) represent a diversity of UAS platforms (10 different models) flying at different altitudes and for eight distinctly different missions; (3) consist of video, still imagery, and photogrammetric data products based on mission; and (4) include flights before the event, during the response phase, and through the restoration phase. However, the datasets require some additional work to screen content for privacy, to complete meta-data, to be consistent in naming conventions in order to facilitate access by external researchers, and to set up controlled access. The datasets are ephemeral because the missing meta-data of pilots, platforms, and flight times for each mission will be lost in the memory of the pilots and because the datasets are needed to enable other researchers in computing and engineering use the data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created a public dataset of the small unmanned aerial system imagery and performance data taken by the Center for Robot-Assisted Search and Rescue for Hurricanes Harvey and Irma. These two deployments are the two largest ever reported by emergency managers and thus form a treasure trove of information for researchers and industry. Hurricane Harvey had 112 flights and Irma 139, but just as important, the flights represent a diversity of UAS platforms (10 different models) flying at different altitudes and for eight distinctly different missions;  consist of video, still imagery, and photogrammetric data products based on mission; and include flights before the event, during the response phase, and through the restoration phase. The data was screened for privacy and any regulatory prohibitions and then posted online at hrail.crasar.org. The data can be used by researchers in robotics, cyber-physical systems, intelligent systems, natural hazards, manufacturing, infrastructure resilience, and computing. It is already been downloaded by nearly 30 organizations and is being used to test out computer vision and machine learning algorithms. The lessons learned about which small UAS were used for what missions during what phase of the disaster is also being used by emergency managers to determine how to best adopt small UAS for disasters. The data was used to guide and direct the deployment of small UAS in the aftermath of Hurricane Micheal.
